content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Its a good puzzle, thanks.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Very fun puzzle, I thinking this puzzle doesn't follow the statements until I read the results of previous tests.
The needs to read previous answer to find all the rules is not obvious but it's not so difficult to find.
The rules of the # and % and not specified in the statement

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Very original puzzle with added rules in test cases !

"Any time a star (*) is observed in the encoded message, the most recently observed (but not discarded) character should be added to the end of the decoded message."
=> You should add that the added character should then be discarded.
=> Strictly speaking, (*) is also a character that is observed. I expect some people to add the (*) itself to the decoding message.

One suggestion :
Any time a star (*) is observed in the encoded message, the most recently observed character that is not a star and that has not been discarded should be added to the end of the decoded message and should be then discarded from the observed characters.

Interesting puzzle, I think it's the first one I've done where extra rules were stated in the tests. Was it your intention for us to guess it? If so, why not, it's an original take. If instead it was a miss, I'd suggest to add a simple line after the (*) explanation, along the lanes:
- Further instructions will be received via the decoded messages.

Also, this:
"Next line: An integer length indicating the length of the encoded message."
It's not strictly true, it's the length of the encoded message string without the "+" characters. For example, in the first test:
>>> 716 (given length int by the input)
>>> 1430 (actual length of encoded_message string)

Not really a big fan of the new rules being implemented and only being able to be found within the test case result themselves. This prompt is already super confusing, doesn't need extra confusion on top of it in my opinion.

Goal section
* I do not understand the example (t+c+*+a+*+*). Would it be possible to give a step-by-step illustration of how the decoding in that example?

* Please specify whether case matters in applying character swap rules. For example, does a rule of "w -> d" mean that only the lowercase "w" should be replaced, but not the uppercase "W"?

Input section
* Instead of "Line n+2" and "Line n+3" you may consider simplifying them to "Next line".

Constraints section
* Please add a space before "2000".

Thanks.

Hello Tim,

It was not obvious for me to understand how stars interact with the text. The concept of "observed" and "used" was not clear for example.
I had to manually go through the example to finally get it. 
Maybe replacing all "used" by "discarded" could help.
Also, the encoded message for the "cat" example could be : t+c+*+a+*+*
It would give a better intuition of what's going on.

My next concern is about the length of the encoded message. I think you should add it before. It will be very useful for languages like C.

Otherwise it's a nice puzzle !

I just discovered that the problem get more and more complex as you resolve test cases.
Nice idea !

I made the changes you suggested.  I made some changes to the 'cat' example, but I'm struggling to do more without it looking like pseudo-code for the solution.  Using the new write-up, I ran some pen and paper tests with family members and the results were reasonable...and very entertaining.

Thank you for the feedback!

Just finished the puzzle. Thinking about it now, the new rules in the test cases isn't a bad idea, but just make sure to hint at it somewhere in the initial instructions. One small issue I had is that I think you need to specify better that there can't be any double spaces in between words. You do specify in the Output section that "no string has leading or trailing spaces", but this just sounds like you need to strip the spaces from the start and end of each line which led to me having a bit of trouble at first getting the decoding to work due to these double spaces that I thought were fine.

Great catch!  I added those lengths yesterday and I just flat out did it wrong.  I will fix those today.

It was indeed my intention to not say anything in the instructions about the additional rules. So often in what we do, the small details are super important.  I expect there is a temptation with a puzzle like this to just code it up, run it and expect to get perfect results...without ever reading the output. Only after reading the decoded output does it become clear what went wrong.  This is also why I added the requirement to print the decoded message on multiple lines.
Let me know what you think of the revision I just made.
Correct.  That is by design.
Thanks kayou!  That is exactly what I'm hoping for..."not so difficult to find"...and a little reward for searching through the details.
My pleasure.  Thank you for taking the time to look at it!

Sure, I liked the touch, although I can only guess that some people will find it confusing (it was for me at least), but oh well.

Cool puzzle though. I'll wait a bit before testing it again in case you end up changing something else.

The double spaces are a bad habit on my part.  I will remove all double spaces today.

I did intentionally leave out any information about additional rules coming in decoded messages.  Yes, the puzzle is coded as "easy", but even easy problems in life have unexpected twists.  I wanted to add a feature to the puzzle that highlighted the importance of attention to detail.  In this case, the attention to detail being reading the output of each test case.  I appreciate your input and I'll see what others have to say and then decide whether to put a hint in or not.

I added this to the end:

"These messages are extremely important. Make sure your commanding officer reads every word!"

Do you think that is enough of a hint, without completely giving it away?

Thank you.

You may actually consider presenting a table like this, more visualised :)

(Use the `monospace syntax` for correct alignment)

`character    characters
in encoded   observed     decoded
message      and kept     message
   t            t         (nothing yet)
   +            t         (nothing yet)
   c            t, c      (nothing yet)
   +            t, c      (nothing yet)
   *            t            c
   +            t            c
   a            t, a         c
   *            t            ca
   +            t            ca
   *         (nothing)       cat`
Thank you for taking a look!  I will incorporate your ideas and make it public.
